t:intro.p: The EigenvectorCentrality function calculates the centrality (relative importance) of each node in a graph.

td.div: Element in matrix that represents relationship between vertex i and vertex j

t:intro.p: Bonacich (1972) suggests that the eigenvector of the largest eigenvalue of an adjacency matrix could make a good network centrality measure. He defines Eigenvector Centrality as:
For more information about this formula, see:

p.i: Bonacich, P. Factoring and Weighting Approaches to Status Scores and Clique Identification. Journal of Mathematical Sociology 2 (1972), 113-120.

t:intro.p: Katz (1953) gives a measure of centrality as:
For more information about this formula, see:

p.i: Katz, L. A New Status Index Derived from Sociometric Analysis. Psychometrika 18 (1953), 39-43.

t:intro.p: Bonacich (1987) writes a more generic centrality measure as:
Note: a and b are exchanged in the above formula (compared to the original one) to be consistent with Katz centrality.
For more information about this formula, see:

p.i: Bonacich, P. Power and Centrality: A Family of Measures. American Journal of Sociology 92 (1987), 1170-1182.

t:intro.p: An eigenvector of a square matrix Α is a nonzero vector υ such that Αυ=λυ. The number λ is called the eigenvalue of Α corresponding to υ.
The eigenvalues of a matrix Α can be determined by finding the roots of the characteristic polynomial of equation det(Α−λI) = 0.

Power iteration is an eigenvalue algorithm to find the largest eigenvalue and corresponding eigenvector. This algorithm does not compute a matrix decomposition; therefore, you can use it when Α is a very large sparse matrix.
The power iteration algorithm starts with a vector b 0, which can be an approximation to the dominant eigenvector or a random vector. This iteration describes the method:

b
k+1 = A b
k / || A b
k ||

At every iteration, the vector b
k is multiplied by matrix Α and normalized.

ul.li: A has an eigenvalue that is strictly greater in magnitude than its other eigenvalues.
Starting vector b 0 has a nonzero component in the direction of an eigenvector associated with the dominant eigenvalue.

t:intro.p: To calculate centrality using the formulas described in Centrality Formulas, the EigenvectorCentrality function uses an in-neighbors relation matrix of the input source key and target key. In this matrix, aij has the value 1 if there is an edge from j to i.
If you need an out-neighbors adjacent matrix—for example, to calculate the contribution of a vertex to other vertices—exchange the source key and target key columns and then invoke this function.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM EigenvectorCentrality ( ON vertices_table AS Vertices PARTITION BY vertex_key_column [,...] ON edges_table AS Edges PARTITION BY source_vertex_key_column [,...] USING TargetKey ({ 'edge_attribute' | edge_attribute_range }[,...]) [ EdgeWeight (edge_weight) ] [ Family ({ 'eigenvector' | 'katz' | 'bonacich' }) ] [ Alpha (alpha_value) ] [ Beta (beta_value) ] [ Directed ({'true'|'t'|'yes'|'y'|'1'|'false'|'f'|'no'|'n'|'0'}) ] [ MaxIterNum (max_iteration_number) ] [ StopThreshold (threshold) ] [ Accumulate ({ 'accumulate_column' | accumulate_column_range }[,...]) ] ) AS alias;

div.dd: Specify the names of the target key columns in the Edges table. The number and data types of columns must correspond to those of vertex_key.
[Optional] Specify the name of the Edges table column that contains the edge weights. The edge weights must be positive values.
Default behavior: The graph is unweighted.

[Optional] Specify the centrality formula:
'eigenvector' (Default)
'katz'
'bonacich'
For descriptions of the centrality formulas, see Centrality Formulas.
[Optional] Specify the alpha value for the Katz or Bonacich centrality formula.
[Optional] Specify the beta value for the Katz or Bonacich centrality formula.
Default: 1 for Katz and 0 for Bonacich
[Optional] Specify whether the graph is directed.
[Optional] Specify the maximum number of iterations for the function.
[Optional] Specify the threshold for convergence (the difference of between b k+1 and b k).
[Optional] Specify the names of the Vertices columns to copy to the output table.

t:intro.p: Each row represents a vertex of the graph. The table can have additional columns, but the function ignores them.

td.div: Any allowed in PARTITION BY clause
[Column appears once for each specified vertex_key_column.] All or part of unique vertex key. Cannot be NULL.
[Column appears once for each specified accumulate_column.] Column to copy to output table.

t:intro.p: Each row represents an edge of the graph. The table can have additional columns, but the function ignores them.

td.div: Any allowed in PARTITION BY clause
Column appears once for each specified source_vertex_key_column.] All or part of key that identifies source vertex of edge. Must be a vertex_key_column in Vertices table. Cannot be NULL.
Column appears once for each specified target_vertex_key_column.] All or part of key that identifies target vertex of edge. Must be a vertex_key_column in Vertices table. Cannot be NULL.
[Required only for weighted graph.] Edge weight, a positive value. Can be NULL.
[Column appears once for each specified accumulate_column.] Column to copy to output table.
[Column appears once for each specified accumulate_column.] Column copied from input table.

t:intro.p: In the following figure, nodes represent college sophomores and edges represent the number of elective subjects that both sophomores have taken.
The graph in the figure is represented by the Vertices and Edges tables sophomores and common_classes, respectively.
Family is 'eigenVector' by default.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM EigenvectorCentrality ( ON sophomores AS Vertices PARTITION BY id ON common_classes AS Edges PARTITION BY startid USING TargetKey ('endid') Accumulate ('id') EdgeWeight ('electives') ) AS dt ORDER BY centrality DESC;

t:intro.p: Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
Both input tables are from EigenvectorCentrality Example: Eigenvector Centrality:

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM EigenvectorCentrality ( ON sophomores AS Vertices PARTITION BY id ON common_classes AS Edges PARTITION BY startid USING TargetKey ('endid') Accumulate ('id','name') Family ('katz') EdgeWeight ('electives') ) AS dt;

t:intro.p: Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
Input tables are from EigenvectorCentrality Example: Eigenvector Centrality:

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM EigenvectorCentrality ( ON sophomores AS Vertices PARTITION BY id ON common_classes AS Edges PARTITION BY startid USING TargetKey ('endid') Accumulate ('id') Family ('bonacich') Beta (0.01) EdgeWeight ('electives') ) AS dt ORDER BY centrality DESC;

t:intro.p: Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
